course.title: Integrated math 3
course.description: The Mathematics 3 course, often taught in the 11th grade, covers Polynomials; Logarithms; Transformations of functions; an extension of the worlds of Equations and Modeling; Trigonometric functions; Rational functions; and an extension of the world of Statistics and Probability. Khan Academy's Mathematics 3 course is built to deliver a comprehensive, illuminating, engaging, and Common Core aligned experience!

units.title: Polynomial arithmetic
units.description: Polynomials get their name from the prefix "poly", which means many. In this unit, you'll learn what polynomials are and the many things that you can do with polynomials - including addition, subtraction, and multiplication. This also paves the way for factoring and dividing polynomials.

items.title: Polynomials intro
items.description: This introduction to polynomials covers common terminology like terms, degree, standard form, monomial, binomial and trinomial. Polynomials are sums of terms of the form k⋅xⁿ, where k is any number and n is a positive integer. For example, 3x+2x-5 is a polynomial.

items.title: Polynomials intro
items.description: Review your knowledge of basic terminology for polynomials: degree of a polynomial, leading term/coefficient, standard form, etc.

items.title: The parts of polynomial expressions
items.description: Discover the magic of polynomials! Learn to identify terms, coefficients, and exponents in a polynomial. Understand that terms are the parts being added, coefficients are the numbers multiplying the powers of x, and exponents are the powers to which x is raised. Dive into the world of polynomials and make math fun!

lessons.title: Average rate of change of polynomials

items.title: Finding average rate of change of polynomials
items.description: Learn how to calculate the average rate of change of a function over a specific interval. Discover how changes in the function's value relate to changes in x. Use tables and visuals to understand the concept better. This is key to mastering polynomial functions in algebra.

items.title: Sign of average rate of change of polynomials
items.description: Discover how to find the average rate of change in polynomials. Learn to identify intervals with positive average rates of change by comparing function values at different points. See how this concept applies to real-life situations, making math fun and practical!

items.title: Average rate of change of polynomials
items.description: Find the average rate of change of a function over a given interval.

items.title: Adding polynomials
items.description: Learn how to simplify polynomials by combining like terms! Discover the power of adding and subtracting terms with the same degree of x. Uncover the magic of removing parentheses and grouping similar terms together to simplify complex expressions. Master the art of polynomial simplification!

items.title: Add polynomials (intro)
items.description: Example: Add (2x²-3) and (7x³-4x+1).

items.title: Subtracting polynomials
items.description: Master the art of adding and subtracting polynomials! Learn how to distribute negative signs across terms, combine like terms, and simplify expressions. This skill is key to understanding algebra and making math easier.

items.title: Subtract polynomials (intro)
items.description: Example: Evaluate (4x²-3) - (3x³-3x+2).

items.title: Polynomial subtraction
items.description: Learn how to subtract polynomials. Discover how distributing a negative sign changes the signs of all terms in a polynomial. Understand that when you subtract polynomials, you still get a polynomial, showing that the set of polynomials is 'closed' under subtraction.

items.title: Add & subtract polynomials
items.description: Example: Subtract -2x²+4x-1 from 6x²+3x-9.

items.title: Adding and subtracting polynomials review
items.description: Adding and subtracting polynomials is all about combining like terms. In this article, we review some examples and give you a chance for you to practice the skill yourself.

items.title: Multiplying monomials
items.description: Learn how to multiply monomials like a pro! Discover how to multiply numbers and variables separately, then combine them for the final answer. Explore how exponent properties come into play when multiplying variables. Dive into examples with different variables for variety.

items.title: Multiply monomials
items.description: Express the product of two monomial expressions as a single monomial

items.title: Multiplying monomials by polynomials: area model
items.description: Discover how to calculate the area of complex shapes using algebra! By breaking down a rectangle into smaller parts, we can find the total area by multiplying the height and width of each part. This method introduces us to the concept of multiplying monomials by polynomials.

items.title: Area model for multiplying polynomials with negative terms
items.description: Discover how to multiply monomials by polynomials using area models. This method works even when dealing with negative terms! By visualizing the process, we can understand why we multiply different terms and how negative areas affect the total area.

items.title: Multiply monomials by polynomials: area model
items.description: Use area to understand how to multiply monomials by polynomials.

items.title: Multiplying monomials by polynomials
items.description: Discover how to multiply monomials by polynomials using the distributive property. Learn to simplify expressions by multiplying coefficients and adding exponents. Get a handle on negative terms and see how they affect the final result. It's all about breaking down complex problems into simpler steps!

items.title: Multiply monomials by polynomials
items.description: Use the distributive property to express the product of a monomial and a polynomial as a single polynomial.

items.title: Multiplying monomials by polynomials review
items.description: We use the distributive property to multiply monomials by polynomials. For example, 2x(3x+7) = 6x^2+14x. This article provides a brief review of the topic and gives you a couple of practice problems to try on your own.

items.title: Multiplying binomials by polynomials: area model
items.description: Discover the magic of multiplying binomials by polynomials using an area model! This method transforms complex algebra into simple rectangles, making it easier to understand. By breaking down the big rectangle into smaller ones, we can find the area and thus the product of the polynomials.

items.title: Multiply binomials by polynomials: area model
items.description: Get some initial practice in multiplying binomials by polynomials, using the polynomial area model.

items.title: Multiplying binomials by polynomials
items.description: Learn how to multiply binomials by polynomials with ease! This lesson breaks down the process into simple steps, using the distributive property to multiply each term. You'll master combining like terms to simplify expressions, turning complex polynomials into manageable math.

items.title: Multiply binomials by polynomials
items.description: Use the distributive property to express the product of a binomial and a polynomial as a single polynomial.

items.title: Multiplying binomials by polynomials review
items.description: A review of how to multiply binomials like 1 + x by polynomials with more than two terms like x^2 - 5x - 6

items.title: Polynomial special products: difference of squares
items.description: Dive into the exciting world of special products of polynomials, focusing on the difference of squares. We explore how to expand and simplify algebraic expressions. We also tackle more complex expressions, applying the same principles to make math magic happen!

items.title: Polynomial special products: difference of squares
items.description: Find products of binomials that have the special form "difference of squares."

items.title: Polynomial special products: perfect square
items.description: Squaring binomials is a breeze when you recognize patterns! The perfect square pattern tells us that (a+b)²=a²+2ab+b². The video shows how to square more complex binomials. It's all about applying what we know about simple binomials to these trickier ones.

items.title: Polynomial special products: perfect square
items.description: Find special products (perfect squares and difference of squares) of "advanced" binomials: binomials with leading coefficients other than 1; binomials with higher degrees; and binomials with two variables.

units.title: Polynomial factorization
units.description: Take your polynomials skills to the next level as you learn how to rewrite polynomials in degrees higher than 2 as products of linear factors. This approach will give you the skills you need to investigate polynomial functions and to prove polynomial identities that describe numerical relationships.

items.title: Introduction to factoring higher degree polynomials
items.description: Unpack the process of factoring monomials in algebra. Learn to simplify third-degree polynomials and tackle fourth-degree monomials. Understand the structure of introductory algebra and apply it to higher degree polynomials. Explore the concept of factoring multiple times and delve into the difference of squares. It's all about breaking down complex expressions into simpler parts!

items.title: Introduction to factoring higher degree monomials
items.description: Factoring monomials involves breaking down a single term into the product of other terms. This video explores how to factor monomials, like 6x to the 7th power, into simpler parts. It also introduces the concept of prime factorization, which is useful for factoring higher degree expressions.

items.title: Which monomial factorization is correct?
items.description: Factoring monomials involves breaking down an expression into two parts. This process shows that there are multiple correct ways to factor a monomial. By multiplying coefficients and powers, you can verify if the factorization is accurate. It's a fun exploration of the many ways to dissect monomials!

items.title: Worked example: finding the missing monomial factor
items.description: Follow along as Sal works an example to show you how to factor monomials by isolating variables in equations. Learn how to use exponent properties to rewrite complex expressions and get a firm grasp on the crucial role that coefficients and exponents play in this process. This knowledge will empower you to solve for unknown factors in any monomial equation.

items.title: Worked example: finding missing monomial side in area model
items.description: Learn how to find the length of a rectangle using algebraic expressions, as Sal finds the length of a rectangle whose area is 42xy^3 and whose height is 14xy. Dive into dividing coefficients and variables to solve for length and uncover how dividing powers of 'y' can simplify your equation.

items.title: Factoring monomials
items.description: Learn how to completely factor monomial expressions, or find the missing factor in a monomial factorization.

items.title: Factor monomials
items.description: Factor monomials as products of smaller monomials.

items.title: Greatest common factor of monomials
items.description: Follow along as Sal finds the greatest common factor of 10cd^2 and 25c^3d^2 and discover the secret to finding the greatest common factor of monomials! Dive into prime factorization and variable parts, and learn how to break down monomials into their simplest forms. Uncover the common factors and master the art of algebraic expressions.

items.title: Greatest common factor of monomials
items.description: Learn how to find the GCF (greatest common factor) of two monomials or more.

items.title: Greatest common factor of monomials
items.description: Find the greatest monomial that is a common factor of other monomials. For example, 2x is the greatest common factor of 4x and 6x².

items.title: Taking common factor from binomial
items.description: Explore the process of factoring polynomials using the greatest common monomial factor. This involves breaking down coefficients and powers of variables to find the largest common factor, and then rewriting the expression with this common factor factored out. It's an essential skill for simplifying and solving algebraic expressions

items.title: Taking common factor from trinomial
items.description: Break down the process of taking common factors from trinomials. Learn how to identify the greatest common factor of a trinomial expression and use it to simplify the expression. Follow along as Sal factors 4x⁴y-8x³y-2x² as 2x²(2x²y-4xy-1) by taking the greatest common factor.

items.title: Taking common factor: area model
items.description: The video explores taking common factors in algebra using an area model. It demonstrates how to find the greatest common monomial factor of terms and uses the area of a rectangle as a visual aid. By factoring out the length and width, you can better grasp the process of factoring polynomials.

items.title: Factoring polynomials by taking a common factor
items.description: Learn how to factor a common factor out of a polynomial expression. For example, factor 6x²+10x as 2x(3x+5).

items.title: Factor polynomials: common factor
items.description: Practice finding the greatest common factors of polynomials and factoring them out of the polynomials.

items.title: Factoring higher degree polynomials
items.description: Factoring higher degree polynomials involves breaking down complex expressions into simpler parts. This process includes identifying common factors, using the distributive property, and recognizing perfect squares. Sal demonstrates how to factor a partially factored polynomial and how to factor a third degree polynomial by grouping.

items.title: Factoring higher-degree polynomials: Common factor
items.description: Discover the art of factoring higher degree polynomials. We start by pulling out common factors, then spot perfect squares. The key is seeing patterns and using them to simplify complex expressions. Sal demonstrates by factoring 16x^3+24x^2+9x as (x)(4x+3)^2.

items.title: Factor higher degree polynomials
items.description: Factor polynomials by taking common factors, grouping, and using known quadratic methods.

items.title: Identifying quadratic patterns
items.description: Factoring using structure involves recognizing patterns in expressions, like the difference of squares or perfect square trinomials, and using these patterns to break down complex expressions into simpler ones. As an example, you’ll determine whether the polynomial 9x⁸+6x⁴y+y² can be factored using the perfect square pattern or the difference of squares pattern (or neither).

items.title: Identify quadratic patterns
items.description: Given a polynomial expression whose degree is more than 2, determine whether it can be factored using one of the common quadratic patterns.

items.title: Factorization with substitution
items.description: Unravel the mystery of algebraic expressions with factorization using substitution! This lesson explores how to simplify complex expressions by identifying patterns and substituting variables. By using U+V² and U+V x U-V structures, you can easily transform and factor expressions!

items.title: Factorization with substitution
items.description: Given a polynomial expression whose degree is more than 2, determine the necessary substitution in order to factor it using one of the common quadratic patterns.

items.title: Factoring using the perfect square pattern
items.description: Sal factors 25x^4-30x^2+9 as (5x^2-3)^2.

items.title: Factoring using the difference of squares pattern
items.description: If we expand (a+b)(a-b) we will get a²-b². Factorization goes the other way: suppose we have an expression that is the difference of two squares, like x²-25 or 49x²-y², then we can factor is using the roots of those squares. For example, x²-25 can be factored as (x+5)(x-5). This is an extremely useful method that is used throughout math.

items.title: Factor polynomials using structure
items.description: Factor "advanced" polynomials (i.e. polynomials of various degrees and or with two variables) using special product factorization methods.

items.title: Polynomial identities introduction
items.description: Polynomial identities are equal expressions involving polynomials. We can prove these identities through algebraic manipulation, like expanding and simplifying. This helps us see if two expressions are the same for all values of a variable, making them true polynomial identities.

items.title: Analyzing polynomial identities
items.description: The video focuses on the critical analysis of polynomial manipulations, emphasizing the importance of checking each step for errors. It provides practice on identifying valid polynomial identities and highlights the significance of correct algebraic multiplication in solving polynomial equations.

items.title: Polynomial identities
items.description: Determine whether given polynomial identities are true, and whether given proofs of such identities are valid.

items.title: Describing numerical relationships with polynomial identities
items.description: Explore numerical relationships in polynomial identities, demonstrating how they can reveal patterns in sequences of integer squares. Learn how algebra can prove that the difference between successive terms in a sequence of integer squares is always an increasing odd number.

items.title: Geometric series introduction
items.description: Learn how money grows in a bank account with geometric series! Discover how each deposit grows by a fixed percentage every year, creating a pattern. This pattern forms a geometric series, a useful concept in finance and business. Keep depositing and watch your money multiply!

items.title: Finite geometric series formula
items.description: A finite geometric series can be solved using the formula a(1-rⁿ)/(1-r). Sal demonstrates how to derive a formula for the sum of the first 'n' terms of such a series, emphasizing the importance of understanding the number of terms being summed.

items.title: Worked examples: finite geometric series
items.description: Get a front row seat to Sal's step-by-step solutions to finite geometric series. Learn how to find the sum of the first 50 terms of a series by multiplying each term by a common ratio. Discover how to apply the formula for the sum of a finite geometric series. Plus, explore how to handle series with a change in sign.

items.title: Geometric series formula
items.description: Practice your understanding of the geometric series formula.

items.title: Geometric series word problems: swing
items.description: The length a monkey passes when swinging from a tree can be modeled by a geometric series!  We learn that each swing's length is half the previous one, forming a finite geometric series. By applying the sum formula, we calculate the total distance the monkey swings.

items.title: Geometric series word problems: hike
items.description: Can a finite geometric series help us plan a hiking trip? Sloan embarks on a four-day hiking trip, increasing her distance by 20% each day. To figure out her first day's distance, we use the finite geometric series formula. This math tool helps us solve Sloan's hiking puzzle.

items.title: Finite geometric series word problems
items.description: Understanding and solving problems with the formula for a finite geometric series

units.title: Polynomial division
units.description: After we have added, subtracted, and multiplied polynomials, it's time to divide them! This will prove to be a little bit more sophisticated. It turns out that not every polynomial division results in a polynomial. When it doesn't, we end up with a remainder (just like with integer division!).

items.title: Polynomial division introduction
items.description: When we divide the polynomial p(x) by q(x) we are basically asking "what should we multiply by q(x) to get p(x)?" If this sounds familiar, it's because it's very similar to dividing numbers! In this introduction we see how some quotients end up as a polynomial, while other times we have a remainder and cannot express the quotient as a polynomial. This is very similar to quotients of integers!

items.title: Dividing polynomials by x (no remainders)
items.description: Discover how to divide polynomials by 'x' in two different ways. Finding the quotient (x⁴-2x³+5x)/x is the same as asking "what should we multiply by x to get x⁴-2x³+5x?" First, we distribute '1/x' to each term in the polynomial. Second, we factor out an 'x' from each term. Both methods simplify complex expressions,

items.title: Divide polynomials by x (no remainders)
items.description: Divide polynomials by x, where the polynomial is divisible by x, so the result is also a polynomial (no remainder).

items.title: Divide polynomials by x (with remainders)
items.description: Learn how to simplify complex expressions by dividing polynomials by 'x'. Discover how to break down the numerator, distribute the division, and use exponent properties. Master the art of simplifying fractions and handling negative exponents. Sal demonstrates by dividing (18x^4-3x^2+6x-4) by 6x.

items.title: Divide polynomials by x (with remainders)
items.description: Divide polynomials by x, where the polynomial isn't divisible by x, so the result has a remainder.

items.title: Intro to long division of polynomials
items.description: Learn how to divide polynomials, also known as algebraic long division. This video starts with simple examples and gradually moves to more complex ones, demonstrating how to divide quadratics by linear factors. The process involves looking at the highest degree terms, dividing, and subtracting to simplify expressions.

items.title: Dividing quadratics by linear expressions (no remainders)
items.description: We can divide polynomials similarly to how we divide integers. For example, when we divide (x²+7x+10) by (x+2), we are asking "what can we multiply by (x+2) to get (x²+7x+10)?" We can answer this question in many ways. One is with using factorization, and another one is long division.

items.title: Divide quadratics by linear expressions (no remainders)
items.description: Divide quadratic expressions by linear expressions, where the linear expression is a factor of the quadratic expression.

items.title: Dividing quadratics by linear expressions with remainders
items.description: Learn how to simplify complex math problems by dividing quadratics by linear factors with remainders. Discover two methods for simplifying these kinds of math problems: factoring the numerator or using algebraic long division. This process helps break down tricky equations, making them easier to solve.

items.title: Dividing quadratics by linear expressions with remainders: missing x-term
items.description: An interesting case in polynomial division is when one of the terms is missing. The video explains how to divide a quadratic expression, like (x²+1), by a linear one, such as (x+2). It shows two methods: re-expressing the numerator and using algebraic long division. Both methods lead to the same answer.

items.title: Divide quadratics by linear expressions (with remainders)
items.description: Divide quadratic expressions by linear expressions, where the linear expression isn't a factor of the quadratic expression, so the division has a remainder.

items.title: Dividing polynomials by linear expressions
items.description: Learn how to divide polynomials by linear factors! This tutorial guides you through the process of algebraic long division, focusing on highest degree terms first. You'll master the art of subtracting polynomials, handling remainders, and rewriting expressions in different forms.

items.title: Dividing polynomials by linear expressions: missing term
items.description: This lesson guides you through the process of dividing polynomials by linear factors, showing you how to neatly organize your work and avoid common errors. You'll learn how to handle missing degree terms and ensure correct subtraction. The result? You'll confidently simplify and rewrite complex rational expressions.

items.title: Divide polynomials by linear expressions
items.description: Rewrite expressions of the form a(x)/b(x), where a is a polynomial b is a linear binomial, in the form q(x)+r(x)/b(x), where q and r are polynomials and the degree of r is less than the degree of b.

items.title: Factoring using polynomial division
items.description: This video breaks down the process of dividing polynomials by linear factors. It starts with a given polynomial and a known factor, then uses polynomial division to rewrite the expression as a product of linear factors.

items.title: Factoring using polynomial division: missing term
items.description: If we know one linear factor of a higher degree polynomial, we can use polynomial division to find other factors of the polynomial. For example, we can use the fact that (x+6) is a factor of (x³+9x²-108) in order to completely factor the polynomial. We just need to be careful because the polynomial has no x-term.

items.title: Factor using polynomial division
items.description: Factor polynomials completely by using known factors and polynomial division.

items.title: Intro to the Polynomial Remainder Theorem
items.description:
The Polynomial Remainder Theorem allows us to determine whether a linear expression is a factor of a polynomial expression easily. It tells us the remainder when a polynomial is divided by 
\[x - a\] is 
\[f(a)\]. This means if 
\[x - a\] is a factor of the polynomial, the remainder is zero. It's a neat trick to quickly find remainders without doing long division!

items.title: Remainder theorem: finding remainder from equation
items.description:
The Polynomial Remainder Theorem simplifies the process of finding the remainder when dividing a polynomial by 
\[x - a\]. Instead of long division, you just evaluate the polynomial at 
\[a\]. This method saves time and space, making polynomial division more manageable.

items.title: Remainder theorem examples
items.description: The polynomial remainder theorem says that for a polynomial p(x) and a number a, the remainder on division by (x-a) is p(a). This might not be very clear right now, but you will understand this much better after watching these examples.

items.title: Remainder theorem
items.description: Use the PRT (Polynomial Remainder Theorem) to determine the factors of polynomials and their remainders when divided by linear expressions.

items.title: Remainder theorem: checking factors
items.description: Learn how to determine if an expression is a factor of a polynomial by dividing the polynomial by the expression. If the remainder is zero, the expression is a factor. The video also demonstrates how to quickly calculate the remainder using the theorem.

items.title: Remainder theorem: finding coefficients
items.description: Learn how to find the value of 'c' that makes 'x - 5' a factor of a polynomial 'p(x)'. Understand how setting 'p(5)' equal to zero and solving for 'c' unveils the mystery. Grasp the concept of the Polynomial Remainder Theorem with a real example.

items.title: Remainder theorem and factors
items.description: Students analyze factors of polynomials by using the polynomial remainder theorem.

items.title: Proof of the Polynomial Remainder Theorem
items.description: The PRT (Polynomial Remainder Theorem) may seem crazy to prove, but Sal shows how you can do it in less than six minutes!

units.title: Polynomial graphs
units.description: In this unit, we will use everything that we know about polynomials in order to analyze their graphical behavior. Specifically, we will find polynomials' zeros (i.e., x-intercepts) and analyze how they behave as the x-values become infinitely positive or infinitely negative (i.e., end-behavior).

items.title: Zeros of polynomials introduction
items.description: The zeros of a polynomial p(x) are all the x-values that make the polynomial equal to zero. They are interesting to us for many reasons, one of which is that they tell us about the x-intercepts of the polynomial's graph. We will also see that they are directly related to the factors of the polynomial.

items.title: Zeros of polynomials: plotting zeros
items.description: When we are given a polynomial in factored form, we can quickly find the polynomial's zeros. Then, we can represent them as the x-intercepts of the polynomial's graph.

items.title: Zeros of polynomials: matching equation to zeros
items.description: When we are given a list of the zeros of a polynomial, we can conclude the polynomial must have certain factors, which gives us information about the equation of the polynomial.

items.title: Zeros of polynomials: matching equation to graph
items.description: When we are given the graph of a polynomial, we can deduce what its zeros are, which helps us determine a few factors the polynomial's equation must include.

items.title: Zeros of polynomials (factored form)
items.description: Select the graph that best suits a polynomial equation by considering the zeros of the polynomial.

items.title: Zeros of polynomials (with factoring): grouping
items.description: When a polynomial is given in factored form, we can quickly find its zeros. When its given in expanded form, we can factor it, and then find the zeros! Here is an example of a 3rd degree polynomial we can factor using the method of grouping.

items.title: Zeros of polynomials (with factoring): common factor
items.description: When a polynomial is given in factored form, we can quickly find its zeros. When it's given in expanded form, we can factor it, and then find the zeros! Here is an example of a 3rd degree polynomial we can factor by first taking a common factor and then using the sum-product pattern.

items.title: Zeros of polynomials (with factoring)
items.description: Use various methods in order to find all the zeros of polynomial expressions or functions.

lessons.title: Positive and negative intervals of polynomials

items.title: Positive and negative intervals of polynomials
items.description: If we know all the zeros of a polynomial, then we can determine the intervals over which the polynomial is positive and negative. This is because the polynomial has the same sign between consecutive zeros. So all we need to do is check each interval that is between two consecutive zeros (or before the smallest zero and after the largest zero).

items.title: Positive & negative intervals of polynomials
items.description: Given a polynomial, determine the intervals in which it is positive or negative.

items.title: Multiplicity of zeros of polynomials
items.description: The polynomial p(x)=(x-1)(x-3)² is a 3rd degree polynomial, but it has only 2 distinct zeros. This is because the zero x=3, which is related to the factor (x-3)², repeats twice. This is called multiplicity. It means that x=3 is a zero of multiplicity 2, and x=1 is a zero of multiplicity 1. Multiplicity is a fascinating concept, and it is directly related to graphical behavior of the polynomial around the zero.

items.title: Zeros of polynomials (multiplicity)
items.description: Given the graph of a polynomial and looking at its x-intercepts, we can determine the factors the polynomial must have. Additionally, we can determine whether those factors are raised to an odd power or to an even power (this is called the multiplicity of the factors).

items.title: Zeros of polynomials (multiplicity)
items.description: Relate polynomials to their graphs, where the polynomials have zeros with multiplicity greater than 1.

items.title: Zeros of polynomials & their graphs
items.description: Learn about the relationship between the zeros, roots, and x-intercepts of polynomials. Learn about zeros multiplicities.

items.title: Positive & negative intervals of polynomials
items.description: Learn about the relationship between the zeros of polynomials and the intervals over which they are positive or negative.

items.title: Intro to end behavior of polynomials
items.description: Sal explains what "end behavior" is and what affects the end behavior of polynomial functions.

items.title: End behavior of polynomials
items.description: Learn what the end behavior of a polynomial is, and how we can find it from the polynomial's equation.

items.title: End behavior of polynomials
items.description: Analyze polynomial functions to determine how they behave as the input variable increases to positive infinity or decreases to negative infinity.

items.title: Graphs of polynomials
items.description: Analyze polynomials in order to sketch their graph.

items.title: Graphs of polynomials: Challenge problems
items.description: Solve challenging problems that tackle the relationship between the features of a polynomial and its graph.

units.title: Logarithms
units.description: Logarithms are the inverses of exponents. They allow us to solve hairy exponential equations, and they are a good excuse to dive deeper into the relationship between a function and its inverse.

items.title: Intro to logarithms
items.description: Sal explains what logarithms are and gives a few examples of finding logarithms.

items.title: Intro to Logarithms
items.description: Learn what logarithms are and how to evaluate them.

items.title: Evaluate logarithms
items.description: Evaluate basic logarithmic expressions by using the fact that a^x=b is equivalent to log_a(b)=x.

items.title: Evaluating logarithms (advanced)
items.description: Sal evaluates log₂(8), log₈(2), log₂(⅛), and log₈(½).

items.title: Evaluate logarithms (advanced)
items.description: Evaluate advanced logarithmic expressions by using the fact that a^x=b is equivalent to log_a(b)=x.

items.title: Relationship between exponentials & logarithms
items.description: Sal rewrites 100=10^2 as a logarithmic equation and log_5(1/125)=-3 as an exponential equation.

items.title: Relationship between exponentials & logarithms: graphs
items.description: Given a few points on the graph of an exponential function, Sal plots the corresponding points on the graph of the corresponding logarithmic function.

items.title: Relationship between exponentials & logarithms: tables
items.description: Given incomplete tables of values of b^x and its corresponding inverse function, log_b(y), Sal uses the inverse relationship of the functions to fill in the missing values.

items.title: Relationship between exponentials & logarithms
items.description: Solve various problems that focus on the relationship between a^x=b and log_a(b)=x.

lessons.title: The constant e and the natural logarithm

items.title: 𝑒 and compound interest
items.description: Sal introduces a very special number in the world of math (and beyond!), the constant 𝑒.

items.title: 𝑒 as a limit
items.description: Sal continues the discussion on e, this time digging deeper into the mathematical definition of 𝑒.

items.title: Evaluating natural logarithm with calculator
items.description: Sal evaluates log_e(67) (which is more commonly written as ln(67) ) using a calculator.

items.title: Intro to logarithm properties (1 of 2)
items.description: Sal introduces the logarithm identities for addition and subtraction of logarithms.

items.title: Intro to logarithm properties (2 of 2)
items.description: Sal introduces the logarithm identities for multiplication of logarithm by a constant, and the change of base rule.

items.title: Intro to logarithm properties
items.description: Learn about the properties of logarithms and how to use them to rewrite logarithmic expressions. For example, expand log₂(3a).

items.title: Using the logarithmic product rule
items.description: Sal rewrites log₃(27x) as log₃(27)+log_3(x), which is simplified as 3+log₃(x).

items.title: Using the logarithmic power rule
items.description: Sal rewrites log₅(x³) as 3log₅(x).

items.title: Use the properties of logarithms
items.description: Use the properties of logarithms in order to rewrite a given expression in an equivalent, different form.

items.title: Using the properties of logarithms: multiple steps
items.description: Sal rewrites log_5([25^x]/y) as 2x-log_5(y) by using both the log subtraction property and the log multiplied by a constant property.

items.title: Proof of the logarithm product rule
items.description: Sal proves the logarithm addition property, log(a) + log(b) = log(ab).

items.title: Proof of the logarithm quotient and power rules
items.description: Sal proves the logarithm quotient rule, log(a) - log(b) = log(a/b), and the power rule, k⋅log(a) = log(aᵏ).

items.title: Justifying the logarithm properties
items.description: Study the proofs of the logarithm properties: the product rule, the quotient rule, and the power rule.

lessons.title: Change of base formula for logarithms

items.title: Evaluating logarithms: change of base rule
items.description: Sal approximates log₅(100) by rewriting it as log(100)/log(5) using the change of base rule, then evaluates with a calculator.

items.title: Logarithm change of base rule intro
items.description: Learn how to rewrite any logarithm using logarithms with a different base. This is very useful for finding logarithms in the calculator!

items.title: Evaluate logarithms: change of base rule
items.description: Evaluate any logarithm in a calculator with the use of the change of base formula. Example: Evaluate log₅(100).

items.title: Using the logarithm change of base rule
items.description: Sal rewrites logarithmic expressions like 1/(logₐ4) or logₐ(16)*log₂(a) using the change of base rule.

items.title: Use the logarithm change of base rule
items.description: Find the logarithmic variable expression that is equivalent to a given logarithmic expression.

items.title: Proof of the logarithm change of base rule
items.description: Sal proves the logarithmic change of base rule, logₐ(b)=logₓ(b)/logₓ(a).

items.title: Logarithm properties review
items.description: Review the logarithm properties and how to apply them to solve problems.

items.title: Solving exponential equations using logarithms: base-10
items.description: Sal solves the equation 10^(2t-3)=7.

items.title: Solving exponential equations using logarithms
items.description: Learn how to solve any exponential equation of the form a⋅b^(cx)=d. For example, solve 6⋅10^(2x)=48.

items.title: Solve exponential equations using logarithms: base-10 and base-e
items.description: Solve exponential equations that have 10 or e at the base of the exponential term.

items.title: Solving exponential equations using logarithms: base-2
items.description:
We can use logarithms to solve *any* exponential equation of the form a⋅bᶜˣ=d. For example, this is how you can solve 3⋅10²ˣ=7:
1. Divide by 3: 10²ˣ=7/3
2. Use the definition of logarithm: 2x=log(7/3)
3. Divide by 2: x=log(7/3)/2 Now you can use a calculator to find the solution of the equation as a rounded decimal number
​

items.title: Solve exponential equations using logarithms: base-2 and other bases
items.description: Solve exponential equations that have 2 or other numbers at the base of the exponential term.

items.title: Exponential model word problem: medication dissolve
items.description: Sal solves an exponential equation in order to answer a question about an exponential model.

items.title: Exponential model word problem: bacteria growth
items.description: Sal evaluates an exponential function at a specific value in order to answer a question about an exponential model.

items.title: Exponential model word problems
items.description: Solve word problems about exponential situations.

units.title: Transformations of functions
units.description: In Mathematics II, you started looking at transformations of specific functions. In this unit, we extend this idea to include transformations of any function whatsoever. This fascinating concept allows us to graph many other types of functions, like square/cube root, exponential and logarithmic functions.

items.title: Shifting functions introduction
items.description: The graph of y=f(x)+k (where k is a real number) is the same as the graph of y=f(x) only it's shifted up (when k>0) or down (when k<0). Similarly, the graph of y=f(x-h) (where h is a real number) is the same as the graph of y=f(x) only it's shifted to the right (when h>0) or to the left (when h<0)

items.title: Shifting functions examples
items.description: Sal analyzes two cases where functions f and g are given graphically, and g is a result of shifting f. He writes formulas for g in terms of f and in terms of x.

items.title: Graphing shifted functions
items.description: Given the graph of f(x)=x², Sal graphs g(x)=(x-2)²-4, which is the graph of f shifted 2 units to the right and 4 units down.

items.title: Shift functions
items.description: Shift functions horizontally and vertically, and practice the relationship between the graphical and the algebraic representations of those shifts.

items.title: Reflecting functions introduction
items.description: We can reflect the graph of y=f(x) over the x-axis by graphing y=-f(x) and over the y-axis by graphing y=f(-x). See this in action and understand why it happens.

items.title: Reflecting functions: examples
items.description: We can reflect the graph of any function f about the x-axis by graphing y=-f(x) and we can reflect it about the y-axis by graphing y=f(-x). We can even reflect it about both axes by graphing y=-f(-x). See how this is applied to solve various problems.

items.title: Reflect functions
items.description: Connect the graphical and algebraic presentations of function reflection across the x-axis and across the y-axis.

items.title: Function symmetry introduction
items.description: Functions can be symmetrical about the y-axis, which means that if we reflect their graph about the y-axis we will get the same graph. There are other functions that we can reflect about both the x- and y-axis and get the same graph. These are two types of symmetry we call even and odd functions.

items.title: Function symmetry introduction
items.description: Learn what even and odd functions are, and how to recognize them in graphs.

items.title: Even and odd functions: Graphs
items.description: Sal picks the function that is odd among three functions given by their graphs.

items.title: Even and odd functions: Tables
items.description: Even functions are symmetrical about the y-axis: f(x)=f(-x). Odd functions are symmetrical about the x- and y-axis: f(x)=-f(-x). Let's use these definitions to determine if a function given as a table is even, odd, or neither.

items.title: Even and odd functions: Graphs and tables
items.description: Given the graph of a function, determine if it's even, odd, or neither.

items.title: Even and odd functions: Equations
items.description: When we are given the equation of a function f(x), we can check whether the function is even, odd, or neither by evaluating f(-x). If we get an expression that is equivalent to f(x), we have an even function; if we get an expression that is equivalent to -f(x), we have an odd function; and if neither happens, it is neither!

items.title: Even and odd functions: Find the mistake
items.description: See another student's work when trying to determine whether a function is even, odd, or either, and decide whether they made a mistake, and if so, where.

items.title: Even & odd functions: Equations
items.description: Given the formula of a polynomial function, determine whether that function is even, odd, or neither.

items.title: Symmetry of polynomials
items.description: Learn how to determine if a polynomial function is even, odd, or neither.

items.title: Scaling functions introduction
items.description: The graph y=k⋅f(x) (where k is a real number) is similar to the graph y=f(x), but each point's distance from the x-axis is multiplied by k. A similar thing happens when we graph y=f(k⋅x), only now the distance from the y-axis changes. These operations are called "scaling."

items.title: Scaling functions vertically: examples
items.description: The function k⋅f(x) is a vertical scaling of f. See multiple examples of how we relate the two functions and their graphs, and determine the value of k.

items.title: Scale functions vertically
items.description: If we multiply a function by a constant, we scale it vertically, which means we either stretch or shrink its vertical dimension. Practice the graphical and algebraic relationship of this transformation.

items.title: Scaling functions horizontally: examples
items.description: The function f(k⋅x) is a horizontal scaling of f. See multiple examples of how we relate the two functions and their graphs, and determine the value of k.

items.title: Identifying horizontal squash from graph
items.description: Given the graphs of functions f and g, where g is the result of compressing f by a factor of 2, Sal finds g(x) in terms of f(x).

items.title: Scale functions horizontally
items.description: If we replace the input of a function with x multiplied by a constant, we scale it horizontally, which means we either stretch or shrink its horizontal dimension. Practice the graphical and algebraic relationship of this transformation.

items.title: Identifying function transformations
items.description: Sal walks through several examples of how to write g(x) implicitly in terms of f(x) when g(x) is a shift or a reflection of f(x).

items.title: Identify function transformations
items.description: Practice the concept of function scaling and the relationship between its algebraic and graphical representations.

lessons.title: Graphs of square and cube root functions

items.title: Graphing square and cube root functions
items.description: We can graph various square root and cube root functions by thinking of them as transformations of the parent graphs y=√x and y=∛x.

items.title: Radical functions & their graphs
items.description: Practice some problems before going into the exercise.

items.title: Graphs of square and cube root functions
items.description: Given the formula of a square-root or a cube-root function, find the appropriate graph.

items.title: Transforming exponential graphs
items.description: Given the graph of y=2ˣ, Sal graphs y=2⁻ˣ-5, which is a horizontal reflection and shift of y=2ˣ.

items.title: Transforming exponential graphs (example 2)
items.description: Given the graph of y=2ˣ, Sal graphs y=(-1)2ˣ⁺³+4, which is a vertical reflection and a shift of y=2ˣ.

items.title: Graphing exponential functions
items.description: Sal graphs y=-2*3ˣ+5 using our interactive graphing widget.

items.title: Graphs of exponential functions
items.description: Graph exponential functions and find the appropriate graph given the function.

items.title: Graphical relationship between 2ˣ and log₂(x)
items.description: Sal graphs y=2ˣ and y=log₂(x) on the same coordinate plane, showing how they relate as graphs of inverse functions.

items.title: Graphing logarithmic functions (example 1)
items.description: We can graph y=2log₂(-x-3) by viewing it as a transformation of y=log₂(x).

items.title: Graphing logarithmic functions (example 2)
items.description: We can graph y=4log₂(x+6)-7 by viewing it as a transformation of y=log₂(x).

items.title: Graphs of logarithmic functions
items.description: Graph logarithmic functions and find the appropriate graph given the function.

units.title: Equations
units.description: We'll learn how to work with rational equations, square-roots, cube-roots, and more! Sometimes we'll even have to watch out for sneaky "extraneous" solutions that aren't actually the right answer. By the end of the unit, you'll be a master of solving all sorts of new equations!

items.title: Rational equations intro
items.description: When we have an equation where the variable is in the denominator of a quotient, that's a rational equation. We can solve it by multiplying both sides by the denominator, but we have to look out for extraneous solutions in the process.

items.title: Rational equations intro
items.description: Solve equations that have one rational expression whose numerator and denominator are linear expressions.

items.title: Equations with rational expressions
items.description: Sal solves (x²-10x+21)/(3x-12)=(x-5)/(x-4), which has one real solution and one extraneous solution.

items.title: Rational equations
items.description: Solve advanced rational equations with multiple expressions.

items.title: Finding inverses of rational functions
items.description: The inverse of a function ƒ is a function that maps every output in ƒ's range to its corresponding input in ƒ's domain. We can find an expression for the inverse of ƒ by solving the equation 𝘹=ƒ(𝘺) for the variable 𝘺. See how it's done with a rational function.

items.title: Find inverses of rational functions
items.description: Given a rational function, find its inverse function.

items.title: Intro to square-root equations & extraneous solutions
items.description: Sal explains what square-root equations are, and shows an example of solving such an equation and checking for extraneous solutions.

items.title: Square-root equations intro
items.description: Sal gives an example of how an extraneous solution arises when solving 2x-1=√(8-x).

items.title: Intro to solving square-root equations
items.description: Practice some problems before going into the exercise.

items.title: Square-root equations intro
items.description: Solve square-root equations by taking the square of both sides.

items.title: Solving square-root equations
items.description: Practice some problems before going into the exercise.

items.title: Solving square-root equations: one solution
items.description: Sal solves the equation 3+√(5x+6)=12.

items.title: Solving square-root equations: two solutions
items.description: Sal solves the equation 6+3w=√(2w+12)+2w which has two solutions.

items.title: Solving square-root equations: no solution
items.description: Sal solves the equation √(3x-7)+√(2x-1)=0, only to find out that the single solution is extraneous, which means the equation has no solution.

items.title: Square-root equations
items.description: Solve square-root equations by first arranging them and then taking the square of both sides.

items.title: Extraneous solutions
items.description: Extraneous solutions are values that we get when solving equations that aren't really solutions to the equation. In this video, we explain how and why we get extraneous solutions, by understanding the logic behind the process of solving equations.

items.title: Equation that has a specific extraneous solution
items.description: Sal finds the value of d for which √(3x+25)=d+2x has an extraneous solution at x=-3.

items.title: Extraneous solutions of radical equations
items.description: Practice some problems before going into the exercise.

items.title: Extraneous solutions of equations
items.description: Practice some problems that involve thinking about the conditions for obtaining extraneous solutions while solving radical equations.

items.title: Solving cube-root equations
items.description: Sal solves the equation -∛y=4∛y+5.

items.title: Quadratic systems: a line and a parabola
items.description: A system of equations that contains one linear equation and one quadratic equations can be solved both graphically and algebraically. Each method has its pros and cons. See an example using both methods.

items.title: Quadratic systems: a line and a circle
items.description: Sal solves the system y=x+1 and x^2+y^2=25.

items.title: Quadratic systems
items.description: Solving systems of two equations where one equation is linear and the other is quadratic.

items.title: Quadratic system with no solutions
items.description: Sal solves a system of two quadratic equations algebraically and finds the system has no solutions. He then graphs the equations to show that this is true.

items.title: Solving equations by graphing
items.description: You probably already solved a system of equations by graphing the equations and looking for intersection points. This method can actually be used to solve (or find an approximate solution to) any single equation, no matter what kind! This is a very exciting tool.

items.title: Solving equations by graphing: intro
items.description: Some equations are hard to solve exactly with algebraic tools. We can always solve an equation by graphing it, although the solution might not be exact. This is an example of how to solve a relatively simple equation graphically.

items.title: Solving equations graphically: intro
items.description: Solve equations of the form f(x)=k where k is an integer and the graph of f is given.

items.title: Solving equations by graphing: graphing calculator
items.description: We can approximate the solutions to any equation by graphing both sides of the equation and looking for intersection points. If we have a graphing calculator, we can get a very good approximation of the solution.

items.title: Solving equations graphically: graphing calculator
items.description: Solve equations of the form f(x)=g(x) by graphing both f and g.

items.title: Solving equations by graphing: word problems
items.description: We can approximate the solutions of any equation by graphing both sides of the equation and looking for intersection point. See how we apply this idea to solve some word problems.

items.title: Solving equations graphically: word problems
items.description: Solve and analyze word problems using the fact that the solution to f(x)=g(x) is represented by the intersection points of the graphs y=f(x) and y=g(x).

units.title: Trigonometry
units.description: In this unit we'll start by learning all about the law of sines and the law of cosines, which can help us figure out the side lengths or angles of a triangle. We'll also get to explore the unit circle, and how it connects to trigonometric functions like sine, cosine, and tangent. Finally, we'll have some fun graphing these functions and learning how to transform them. Get ready to get triggy with it!

items.title: Solving for a side with the law of sines
items.description: Sal is given a triangle with two angle measures and one side length, and he finds all the missing side lengths and angle measures using the law of sines.

items.title: Solving for an angle with the law of sines
items.description: Sal is given a triangle with two side lengths and one angle measure, and he finds all the missing angle measures using the law of sines.

items.title: Solve triangles using the law of sines
items.description: Find missing triangle measures using the law of sines.

items.title: Proof of the law of sines
items.description: Sal gives a simple proof of the Law of sines.

items.title: Solving for a side with the law of cosines
items.description: Learn how to use the law of cosines to find the missing side length of a triangle when given two side lengths and the contained angle measure.

items.title: Solving for an angle with the law of cosines
items.description: Sal is given a triangle with all side lengths but no angle measure, and he finds one of the angle measures using the law of cosines.

items.title: Solve triangles using the law of cosines
items.description: Solve missing triangle measures using the law of cosines.

items.title: Proof of the law of cosines
items.description: Sal gives a simple proof of the Law of cosines.

items.title: Trig word problem: stars
items.description: Sal solves a word problem about the distance between stars using the law of cosines.

items.title: General triangle word problems
items.description: Solve word problems that involve general (non-right) triangles using the law of sines and law of cosines.

items.title: Laws of sines and cosines review
items.description: Review the law of sines and the law of cosines, and use them to solve problems with any triangle.

items.title: Unit circle
items.description: Learn how to use the unit circle to define sine, cosine, and tangent for all real numbers.

items.title: Unit circle
items.description: Practice your understanding of the unit circle definition of sine and cosine.

items.title: The trig functions & right triangle trig ratios
items.description: Sal shows how, for acute angles, the two different definitions of the trigonometric values (SOH CAH TOA and the unit circle definition) result in the same values.

items.title: Trig unit circle review
items.description: Review the unit circle definition of the trigonometric functions.

items.title: Intro to radians
items.description: Sal explains the definition and motivation for radians and the relationship between radians and degrees.

items.title: Radians & degrees
items.description: Sal discusses the general approach to converting between radians and degrees and vice versa.

items.title: Degrees to radians
items.description: To convert from degrees to radians, multiply the number of degrees by π/180. This will give you the measurement in radians. If you have an angle that's 90 degrees, and you want to know what it is in radians, you multiply 90 by π/180. This gives you π/2.

items.title: Radians to degrees
items.description: To change from radians to degrees, you need to multiply the number of radians by 180/π. This number will help you switch between the two units. For example, if you multiply π/2 radians by 180/π, you will get 90 degrees.

items.title: Radians & degrees
items.description: Convert angle measures given in degrees to radians and vice versa.

items.title: Radian angles & quadrants
items.description: Sal determines the quadrant at which a ray falls after a rotation by a certain measure of radians.

items.title: Unit circle (with radians)
items.description: Get more practice with the unit circle definition of sine and cosine, this time with radians instead of degrees.

items.title: Proof of the Pythagorean trig identity
items.description: The Pythagorean identity tells us that no matter what the value of θ is, sin²θ+cos²θ is equal to 1. We can prove this identity using the Pythagorean theorem in the unit circle with x²+y²=1.

items.title: Using the Pythagorean trig identity
items.description: The Pythagorean identity tells us that no matter what the value of θ is, sin²θ+cos²θ is equal to 1. This follows from the Pythagorean theorem, which is why it's called the Pythagorean identity! We can use this identity to solve various problems.

items.title: Use the Pythagorean identity
items.description: Given the sine (or cosine) of an angle, find its cosine (or sine) using the Pythagorean identity.

items.title: Pythagorean identity review
items.description: Review the Pythagorean trigonometric identity and use it to solve problems.

items.title: Trig values of π/4
items.description: Sal finds the trigonometric values of π/4 using the unit-circle definition.

items.title: Trig values of special angles
items.description: Find the sine and cosine of special angles, which are angles whose trig values we can determine without the use of a calculator.

lessons.title: Graphs of sin(x), cos(x), and tan(x)

items.title: Graph of y=sin(x)
items.description: The graph of y=sin(x) is like a wave that forever oscillates between -1 and 1, in a shape that repeats itself every 2π units. Specifically, this means that the domain of sin(x) is all real numbers, and the range is [-1,1]. See how we find the graph of y=sin(x) using the ​unit-circle definition of sin(x).

items.title: Intersection points of y=sin(x) and y=cos(x)
items.description: Sal draws the graphs of the sine and the cosine functions and analyzes their intersection points.

items.title: Graph of y=tan(x)
items.description: Sal draws the graph of the tangent function based on the unit circle definition of the function.

items.title: Features of sinusoidal functions
items.description: Sal introduces the main features of sinusoidal functions: midline, amplitude, & period. He shows how these can be found from a sinusoidal function's graph.

items.title: Midline of sinusoidal functions from graph
items.description: Given the graph of a sinusoidal function, determine its midline equation.

items.title: Amplitude of sinusoidal functions from graph
items.description: Given the graph of a sinusoidal function, determine its amplitude.

items.title: Period of sinusoidal functions from graph
items.description: Given the graph of a sinusoidal function, determine its period.

items.title: Midline, amplitude, and period review
items.description: Review the basic features of sinusoidal functions: midline, amplitude, and period.

items.title: Amplitude & period of sinusoidal functions from equation
items.description: Sal finds the amplitude and the period of y=-0.5cos(3x).

items.title: Transforming sinusoidal graphs: vertical stretch & horizontal reflection
items.description: Sal graphs y=2*sin(-x) by considering it as a vertical stretch and a horizontal reflection of y=sin(x).

items.title: Transforming sinusoidal graphs: vertical & horizontal stretches
items.description: Sal graphs y=-2.5*cos(1/3*x) by considering it as a vertical stretch and reflection, and a horizontal stretch, of y=cos(x).

items.title: Amplitude of sinusoidal functions from equation
items.description: Given the formula of a sinusoidal function, determine its amplitude.

items.title: Midline of sinusoidal functions from equation
items.description: Given the formula of a sinusoidal function, determine its midline equation.

items.title: Period of sinusoidal functions from equation
items.description: Given the formula of a sinusoidal function, determine its period.

items.title: Example: Graphing y=3⋅sin(½⋅x)-2
items.description: Sal graphs y=3⋅sin(½⋅x)-2 by thinking about the graph of y=sin(x) and analyzing how the graph (including the midline, amplitude, and period) changes as we perform function transformations to get from y=sin(x) to y=3⋅sin(½⋅x)-2.

items.title: Example: Graphing y=-cos(π⋅x)+1.5
items.description: Sal graphs y=-cos(π⋅x)+1.5 by thinking about the graph of y=cos(x) and analyzing how the graph (including the midline, amplitude, and period) changes as we perform function transformations to get from y=cos(x) to y=-cos(π⋅x)+1.5.

items.title: Graph sinusoidal functions
items.description: Given the formula of a sinusoidal function of the form a*f(bx)+d, draw its graph.

items.title: Sinusoidal function from graph
items.description: Sal finds the equation of a sinusoidal function from its graph where the minimum point (-2,-5) and the maximum point (2,1) are highlighted.

items.title: Construct sinusoidal functions
items.description: Given a few features of a sinusoidal function, find its formula.

items.title: Graph sinusoidal functions: phase shift
items.description: Given the formula of a sinusoidal function of the form a*f(bx+c)+d, draw its graph.

items.title: Interpreting trigonometric graphs in context
items.description: When a trigonometric function models a real-world relationship, we can assign meaning to its midline, amplitude and period.

items.title: Interpret trigonometric graphs in context
items.description: Analyze real-world situations that are modeled by a trigonometric function.

items.title: Trig word problem: modeling daily temperature
items.description: Sal solves a word problem about the daily change in temperature by modeling it with a sinusoidal function.

items.title: Trig word problem: modeling annual temperature
items.description: Sal solves a word problem about the annual change in temperature by modeling it with a sinusoidal function.

items.title: Model with sinusoidal functions
items.description: Given the description of a real-world relationship, find the sinusoidal function that models it.

items.title: Trig word problem: length of day (phase shift)
items.description: Sal solves a word problem about the annual change in the length of day by modeling it with a sinusoidal function that has a phase shift.

items.title: Modeling with sinusoidal functions: phase shift
items.description: Given the description of a real-world relationship, find the sinusoidal function that models it. The functions in this exercise have a phase (horizontal) shift.

units.title: Modeling
units.description: This unit is all about modeling using functions and formulas. We'll learn how to use them in different ways, from combining them to manipulating them. We'll also learn how to address situations with two or more variables. In short, you'll be mastering some key skills to help you make sense of math in the real world.

items.title: Modeling with function combination
items.description: Sal models the height of a tree on top of a tower, by adding the functions that model the growth of the tree and the tower separately.

items.title: Model with function combination
items.description: Given two basic functions that model a real-world situation, combine them using the appropriate arithmetic operation in order to model a more complex situation.

items.title: Periodicity of algebraic models
items.description: Sal analyzes the periodicity of graphs that model real world situations.

items.title: Periodicity of algebraic models
items.description: Given the graph that models a real world context, answer a question about the periodicity of the graph.

items.title: End behavior of algebraic models
items.description: Sal analyzes the end behavior of graphs that model real world situations.

items.title: End behavior of algebraic models
items.description: Given the graph that models a real world context, answer a question about the end behavior of the graph.

items.title: Symmetry of algebraic models
items.description: Sal interprets the significance of modeling function being even.

items.title: Symmetry of algebraic models
items.description: Learn how to interpret the symmetry of a graph in the context of an applied problem.

items.title: Manipulating formulas: perimeter
items.description: Sal rewrites the formula for the perimeter of a rectangle so it is solved for width.

items.title: Manipulating formulas: area
items.description: Sal rewrites the formula for the area of a triangle so it is solved for height.

items.title: Manipulating formulas: temperature
items.description: Sal takes the formula for converting from Fahrenheit temperature to Celsius, and solves it for F so it serves to convert from Celsius to Fahrenheit.

items.title: Manipulate formulas
items.description: Solve multi-variable formulas for a specific variable in order to solve some word problems.

items.title: Graph labels and scales
items.description: When graphing a real-world relationship, we need to pick labels and axis scales that are appropriate for the purpose of our model.

items.title: Graph labels and scales
items.description: Given the graph of a real-world relationship, determine whether the labels and scales of the graph's axes are appropriate.

items.title: Rational equation word problem
items.description: Sal models a context that concerns the number and price of pizza slices. The model turns out to be a rational equation.

items.title: Quadratic inequality word problem
items.description: Sal models a context that concerns a candy vending machine. The model turns out to be a quadratic inequality.

items.title: Exponential equation word problem
items.description: Sal models a context that concerns a bank savings account. The model turns out to be an exponential equation.

items.title: Equations & inequalities word problems
items.description: Construct an equation or an inequality that model a given context. Modeling expressions can be quadratic, rational, or exponential.

items.title: Modeling with multiple variables: Pancakes
items.description: Modeling the relationship between three quantities (or more) isn't that different from modeling the relationship between two quantities. Here is an example of a model that relates different quantities in the context of making pancakes.

items.title: Modeling with multiple variables: Roller coaster
items.description: Modeling the relationship between three quantities (or more) isn't that different from modeling the relationship between two quantities. Here is an example of a model that relates different quantities in the context of roller coaster rides.

items.title: Modeling with multiple variables
items.description: Create equations in two or more variables to represent relationships between quantities.

items.title: Interpreting expressions with multiple variables: Resistors
items.description: Given the expression for the total resistance in an electric circuit with two resistors, analyze the expression to tell what happens to the total resistance when the resistance of one resistor increases and the resistance of the other resistor stays the same.

items.title: Interpreting expressions with multiple variables: Cylinder
items.description: Given the vale and the expression for the radius of a cylinder, find the radius of a cylinder with the same volume and 100 times the height. This involves analyzing the expression for the radius to see how changing the height affects the radius.

items.title: Interpreting expressions with multiple variables
items.description: Interpret complicated expressions in terms of the real-world situation they model.

units.title: Study Design
units.description: Not only is collecting reliable data exciting, but it's also vital to making sound conclusions. In this unit we'll explore how data collection relates to studies, sampling, observations, surveys, and experiments.

items.title: Reasonable samples
items.description: To make a valid conclusion, you'll need a representaive, not skewed, sample.

items.title: Valid claims
items.description: Practice figuring out whether we took a random sample and whether we're able to draw valid conclusions from our data.

items.title: Making inferences from random samples
items.description: Given a random sample, practice figuring out what can we reasonably infer about the entire population?

items.title: Correlation and causality
items.description: Understanding why correlation does not imply causality (even though many in the press and some researchers often imply otherwise)

items.title: Appropriate statistical study example
items.description: Sal determines if a statistical study was a sample study, an experiment, or an observational study.

items.title: Types of statistical studies
items.description: Determines if a statistical study is a sample study, an experiment, or an observational study.

units.title: Binomial probability
units.description: If you roll five dice, what’s the probability that three of them show a 6? In a group of 20 strangers, what’s the probability that more than half of them were born in the summer? We'll learn all about binomial probability to answer exactly these types of fascinating questions.

items.title: Binomial probability example
items.description: We can use the binomial distribution to find the probability of getting a certain number of successes, like successful basketball shots, out of a fixed number of trials. We use the binomial distribution to find discrete probabilities.

items.title: Generalizing k scores in n attempts
items.description: Sal generalizes 2 scores in 6 attempts to k scores in n attempts.

items.title: Free throw binomial probability distribution
items.description: Sal uses the binomial distribution to calculate the probability of making different number of free throws.

items.title: Graphing basketball binomial distribution
items.description: Sal graphs the results of using the binomial distribution to find the probabilities of making different numbers of free throws.

units.title: Normal distributions
units.description: Let's learn all about Normal distributions! A Normal distribution is both common and crucial in the field of statistics. By describing a wide array of real world phenomena—from exam scores to bug wing lengths—it allows us to better understand and analyze data sets.

items.title: Normal distribution problems: Empirical rule
items.description:
The empirical rule (also called the "68-95-99.7 rule") is a guideline for how data is distributed in a normal distribution.

The rule states that (approximately):

- 68% of the data points will fall within one standard deviation of the mean. 
- 95% of the data points will fall within two standard deviations of the mean. 
- 99.7% of the data points will fall within three standard deviations of the mean.

items.title: Qualitative sense of normal distributions
items.description: Discussion of how "normal" a distribution might be.

items.title: Empirical rule
items.description: Practice applying the 68-95-99.7 empirical rule.

units.title: Rational functions
units.description: This unit on rational functions covers a lot of ground! We'll learn how to simplify, multiply, and divide rational expressions, as well as add and subtract them—whether they're factored or not. We'll also dive into understanding the graphs of rational functions and learn how to use them to model real-world situations.

items.title: Reducing rational expressions to lowest terms
items.description: Learn how to simplify rational expressions, which are fractions with variable expressions in the numerator and denominator. This video also shows how to factor the expressions and cancel out common factors, just like with rational numbers. Don't forget to exclude values of x that would make the denominator zero, since those would make the expression undefined.

items.title: Intro to rational expressions
items.description: Learn what rational expressions are and about the values for which they are undefined.

items.title: Reducing rational expressions to lowest terms
items.description: Learn what it means to reduce a rational expression to lowest terms, and how it's done!

items.title: Simplifying rational expressions: common monomial factors
items.description: Sal simplifies the rational expressions (14x²+7x)/(14x) and (17z³+17z²)/(34z³-51z²) by taking common factors and canceling them.

items.title: Reduce rational expressions to lowest terms: Error analysis
items.description: Analyze other people's attempts to reduce rational expressions to lowest terms, and identify the mistake they made.

items.title: Simplifying rational expressions: common binomial factors
items.description: Given a rectangle with length a²+6a+27 and width a²-9, Sal writes the ratio of the width to the length as a simplified rational expression.

items.title: Simplifying rational expressions: opposite common binomial factors
items.description: Sal simplifies and states the domain of (x^2-36)/(6-x).

items.title: Simplifying rational expressions (advanced)
items.description: Have you learned the basics of rational expression simplification? Great! Now gain more experience with some trickier examples.

items.title: Reduce rational expressions to lowest terms
items.description: Factor the numerator and the denominator of a rational expression and cancel out common binomial terms.

items.title: Simplifying rational expressions: grouping
items.description: Sal simplifies and states the domain of (2x^2+13x+20)/(2x^2+17x+30).

items.title: Simplifying rational expressions: higher degree terms
items.description: Sal simplifies & states the domain of (x⁴+8x²+7)/(3x⁵-3x).

items.title: Simplifying rational expressions: two variables
items.description: Sal simplifies & states the domain of (5x²+20xy+20y²)/(x²-xy-6y²).

items.title: Simplify rational expressions (advanced)
items.description: Factor the numerator and the denominator of a rational expression using advanced methods, and cancel out common terms.

items.title: End behavior of rational functions
items.description: Sal analyzes the end behavior of several rational functions, that together cover all cases types of end behavior.

items.title: End behavior of rational functions
items.description: Given a rational function, determine how it behaves as x approaches +∞ or -∞.

items.title: Discontinuities of rational functions
items.description: Sal analyzes two rational functions to find their vertical asymptotes & removable discontinuities. He distinguishes those from the zeros of the functions.

items.title: Rational functions: zeros, asymptotes, and undefined points
items.description: Given a rational function, sort given input values according to zeros, vertical asymptotes, and removable discontinuities.

items.title: Analyzing vertical asymptotes of rational functions
items.description: Sal analyzes the behavior of q(x)=(x²+3x+2)/(x+3) around its vertical asymptote at x=-3.

items.title: Analyze vertical asymptotes of rational functions
items.description: Given the formula of a rational function, determine how it behaves around its vertical asymptote.

items.title: Graphing rational functions according to asymptotes
items.description: Learn how to find removable discontinuities, horizontal asymptotes, and vertical asymptotes of rational functions. This video explores the specific example f(x)=(3x^2-18x-81)/(6x^2-54) before generalizing findings to all rational functions. Don't forget that not every zero of the denominator is a vertical asymptote!

items.title: Graphs of rational functions: y-intercept
items.description: Sal picks the graph that matches f(x)=(ax^m+bx+12)/(cx^m+dx+12) based on its y-intercept.

items.title: Graphs of rational functions: horizontal asymptote
items.description: Sal picks the graph that matches f(x)=(-x²+ax+b)/(x²+cx+d) based on its horizontal asymptote.

items.title: Graphs of rational functions: vertical asymptotes
items.description: Sal picks the graph that matches f(x)=g(x)/(x²-x-6) (where g(x) is a polynomial) based on its discontinuities.

items.title: Graphs of rational functions: zeros
items.description: Sal picks the graph that matches f(x)=(2x²-18)/g(x) (where g(x) is a polynomial) based on its zeros.

items.title: Graphs of rational functions
items.description: Determine which of four graphs fits the formula of a given function.

items.title: Graphs of rational functions (old example)
items.description: Sal matches three graphs of rational functions to three formulas of such functions by considering asymptotes and intercepts.

items.title: Graphing rational functions 1
items.description: Sal graphs f(x)=(2x+10)/(5x-15).

items.title: Graphing rational functions 2
items.description: Sal graphs y=(2x)/(x+1).

items.title: Graphing rational functions 3
items.description: Sal graphs y=(x^2)/(x^2-16).

items.title: Graphing rational functions 4
items.description: Sal graphs y=(x)/(x^2-x-6).

items.title: Analyzing structure word problem: pet store (1 of 2)
items.description: Sal solves a word problem about the unknown number of bears, cats, and dogs in a pet store. This is part 1 where Sal uses a visual reasoning.

items.title: Analyzing structure word problem: pet store (2 of 2)
items.description: Sal solves a word problem about the unknown number of bears, cats, and dogs in a pet store. This is part 2 where Sal uses an algebraic reasoning.

items.title: Rational equations word problem: combined rates
items.description: Sal solves a word problem about the combined leaf-bagging rates of Ian and Kyandre, by creating a rational equation that models the situation.

items.title: Rational equations word problem: combined rates (example 2)
items.description: Sal solves a word problem about the combined deck-staining rates of Anya and Bill, by creating a rational equation that models the situation.

items.title: Rational equations word problem: eliminating solutions
